# The New York Times

Vol. CLXXIII. . . No. 60,166 6 2024 The New York Times Company SUNDAY, MAY 26, 2024

# Dangers Grow As Workplaces Become Hotter

Punch at Safety Rule Faces Big Hurdles

# OFFICE SEEKERS IN MEXICO FACING A LETHAL THREAT

CARTELS SPREAD FEAR

# By CORAL DAVENPORT AND NOAH WEINBERG

WASHINGTON — For more than two years, a group of health experts, economists and lawyers in the U.S. government has worked to address a growing regulatory health crisis: people dying on the job from a number of causes.

In the coming months, this looming of roughly 30 people at the Occupational Safety and Health Administration is expected to prompt a new rate law that would require employers to protect an estimated 30 million people exposed to long-term exposures while they work. They include farm laborers and construction workers, but also people who may engage in work involving hazardous chemicals and cooks in commercial kitchens.

The measure would be the first major federal government regulation to protect American workers based on the job. And it is expected to meet off-the-shelf threats to some industries and regulatory groups, which oppose regulations that would, in some cases, require more breaks and access to water, aside and air conditioning.

But even if the rule takes effect, experts say, its governance and emergency response systems in poorly suited to meet the urgent needs of workers.

Last year was the hottest on record for the United States, with a 1.5°F increase in average temperature and a 1.5°F increase in average temperature. The heat has been felt across the country, with temperatures above 100 degrees in the South. The heat has been felt in the Northeast, with temperatures above 90 degrees in the Northeast. The heat has been felt in the Midwest, with temperatures above 90 degrees in the Midwest. The heat has been felt in the West, with temperatures above 90 degrees in the West.

The heat has been felt in the West, with temperatures above 90 degrees in the West. The heat has been felt in the Midwest, with temperatures above 90 degrees in the Midwest.

The heat has been felt in the Midwest, with temperatures above 90 degrees in the Midwest. The Midwest has been feeling the heat, with temperatures above 90 degrees in the Midwest.
